awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Personalized Real-Time Learning of Optimal Diagnostic Tests using Multi-Modal Clinical Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project harnesses the growing amount of data that is captured in the electronic health record to discover the optimal diagnostic pathway for an individual patient. A multidisciplinary team with expertise in decision modeling, radiology/clinical practice, informatics, and machine learning will investigate approaches that transform data into actionable knowledge, enabled by a new class of clinical decision support algorithms that actively learn from available clinical data. The objective of this project is to develop and evaluate a data-driven framework for decision support that helps clinicians to deliver individualized patient care by discovering optimal sequences of actions and to diagnose patients in a timely, accurate, and cost-effective manner. The project addresses challenges related to finding relevant information from large, longitudinal patient data; learning sequences of actions from past patient cases; and handling uncertainty that is inherent to the practice of medicine. The new algorithms will improve how observational clinical data can be used to generate evidence that improves healthcare delivery, efficiency, and ultimately, realizes precision medicine and improves patient outcomes. A diverse group of graduate students will be trained in an interdisciplinary manner to translate algorithms and data science concepts into applications that have real-world clinical utility, and with a clear understanding of the technical and cognitive challenges.


The proposed research will create a generalizable framework for learning from healthcare data to discover optimal actions for individual patients with the following objectives: (1) to determine what combination of diagnostic procedures (e.g., imaging, labs, biopsy) should be used to achieve an accurate and timely diagnosis, and in what sequence; and (2) to demonstrate that learning such pathways can be done using available data, allowing the new methodology to be applied in a wide range of clinical domains. Novel aspects of this project are three-fold: (1)Dealing with an environment that is unknown and changing over time in unpredictable ways through a novel adaptive learning approach to discover the most informative features that are predictive of subsequent actions taken in real-time. This builds upon earlier work in relevance learning to dynamically elucidate the relationships between clinical features and possible actions. (2)Developing a new type of bandit algorithm that not only discovers the next best diagnostic test to order, but also identifies additional information that is needed to make a definitive diagnosis. The accuracy and value of diagnostic tests are dependent on many factors (e.g., technology, patient characteristics). The team will assess how prior information from similar patients can speed-up learning given these factors. (3)Providing confidence bounds about the risks and benefits of selecting a specific diagnostic exam to perform. These confidence bounds can be easily understood by clinicians. The performance and utility of this approach will be demonstrated using a prospective study that solicits physician feedback about specific recommendations for a given patient case and learns from situations in which the physician does not follow the system's recommendation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The generation and collection of biomedical data as part of patient care is far outpacing clinicians’ abilities to leverage this information effectively. This project, funded under the Smart and Connected Health program, developed and validated data-driven artificial intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML) algorithms capable of transforming unstructured clinical data into recommended actions and management plans for more accurate and timely diagnosis and treatment of individuals. Specific challenges addressed in the project included: 1) handling incomplete and inconsistent data captured in the electronic health record, 2) overcoming heuristics and biases inherent in how medicine is practiced and reflected in the data, 3) modeling the decision making process of clinicians, and 4) developing models that are transparent and explainable to increase trustworthiness to practitioners. The project proposed a number of AI/ML techniques for patient clustering, uncertainty quantification, model explainability, survival analysis, individualized treatment effect estimation, and longitudinal/time series analysis. Some of the algorithmic developments are highlighted below.

 As electronic health records capture data across an individual’s lifespan, AI/ML models can be used to achieve a deeper understanding of an individual’s health trajectory, including what observations are needed to accurately represent a patient’s condition, how to infer a patient’s current condition, and what triggers a decline in condition. In Smedley et al (2018), we used a sequential pattern mining algorithm to discover temporal patterns using features from clinical and imaging measurements. We demonstrated the ability of this approach to discover temporal patterns that are early indicators of patient decline, allowing clinicians to modify ineffective treatment regimens earlier. In Lee et al (2020), we proposed a neural network-based approach for survival analysis called Dynamic-DeepHit, which learns a data-driven distribution of first event times of competing events, removing the need for explicit model specifications. We showed, using data from a large registry of cystic fibrosis patients, how Dynamic-DeepHit achieved performance improvements in predicting respiratory failure compared to other survival analysis techniques.

Medical decision making involves collecting observations (often through costly tests) about the patient’s condition and developing a differential diagnosis based on the accumulated evidence. To optimize the management of individual patients, AI/ML methods need the ability to model clinicians' decision-making strategies and assign meaningful costs/rewards to decisions (e.g., which test to order). In Petousis et al (2018), we tackled the reward estimation problem by applying an adaptive inverse reinforcement learning approach, showing that using the learned rewards, a partially observable Markov decision process could be instantiated that matched or exceeded human readers’ abilities to recommend when a patient undergoing lung cancer screening should be biopsied. In Jarrett et al (2020), we proposed an inverse active sensing framework to model a physician’s information-seeking behavior, utilizing a Bayesian recognition model to model clinicians’ decision strategies and preferences. We showed how this approach models intuitive notions of surprise, suspense, and optimality in decision strategies.

Data-driven models are increasingly more complex and “black box”, obscuring end users’ abilities to understand how models reached a specific conclusion or troubleshoot the model if it provides incorrect recommendations. The ability to limit and quantify model uncertainty by providing valid and accurate prediction intervals is critical for the translation of AI/ML algorithms in healthcare. In Alaa et al (2020), we developed a principled frequentist approach for estimating uncertainty in the predictions of RNNs. Jackknife resampling was used to create multiple versions of an RNN, and the outputs of each RNN were then analyzed to generate a confidence interval around the jackknife residuals. In Shen et al (2019), we investigated a multi-task deep neural network called the Hierarchical Semantic Convolutional Neural Network (HSCNN) that was trained to classify nodules detected in volumetric computed tomography data as benign or malignant. As part of this prediction, the architecture of the network consisted of several subtasks, each related to generating an interpretable label (e.g., semantic feature) associated with the deep features that are learned from the shared representation layers.

The project has broadly impacted the fields of healthcare, AI/ML, and informatics. The project involved 2 postdoctoral fellows, 8 graduate students, and 4 undergraduates. Results of the project were disseminated in over 20 peer-reviewed journal articles, 50 conference papers, and 10 preprint manuscripts. Project investigators have given numerous keynote and scientific talks in various clinical, informatics, and AI/ML venues. The project tackled wide-ranging applications from cancer screening to adaptive clinical trials, management of limited resources during a pandemic, organ transplantation, and pharmacology. Practitioners worldwide provided feedback on the suitability of the algorithms in clinical practice. As a result, multiple strategies for leveraging data-driven AI/ML approaches are in varying stages of clinical translation. Investigated concepts were also incorporated into a graduate-level course on medical decision making. The source code for many projects has been publicly released to the community and widely downloaded or cited.


 


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: William Hsu
